utterances: As Genteel goes on, Lyons' face falls a bit.
We just came by to get some cherry pie, and we find friends all standing here.
I want you to know that we really care about what's happening in DeWitt and Lansing and Central Michigan and all of Michigan and all of the country.
We're concerned about the people of this great country.
But then this friendly banter takes a quick turn into an attack on the president.
Most often, it's about Mr. Obama's handling of the economy.
This was on that riverboat in Iowa Monday afternoon.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
I hope things are getting better.
I think they are, in the economy.
I sure hope so.
But it's no thanks to him.
It's in spite of him.
And then comes a topic that never gets left out: health care, and Romney's pledge to repeal the law signed by the president in 2010.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
Talk to the person who runs this boat, talk to people on the shore, whether they're in retail or distribution or manufacturing and say: Did Obamacare help you add more jobs?
And they'll say no.
Along the way, Romney was also joined by prominent Republicans in each state, none more so than Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, fresh off his recall battle.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
We need a leader who believes in more freedom and more prosperity, a leader who believes in America and believes that our best days are yet to come.
We need a leader, and that leader is Governor Mitt Romney.
Let's give him a warm, Wisconsin welcome.
Romney, congratulating Walker on defeating the recall attempt earlier this month, made a prediction.
(SOUNDBITE OF SPEECH)
I think President Obama had just put this in his column.
He just assumed from the very beginning Wisconsin was going to be his.
But you know what?
We're going to win Wisconsin.
We're going to get the White House.
Romney made a similar prediction about Michigan.
President Obama easily carried both states last time.
Polls still put him ahead, but Romney hopes to put both in play.
There were protests that trailed Romney as he rode the bus this past week, but they were generally kept down the street and a good distance from the candidate.
Hey, hey, ho, ho, Mitt Romney's got to go.
Hey, hey, ho, ho...
In years past, when a presidential campaign has held a big, multistate bus tour, it's been big national news with big crowds.
This Romney tour seemed to have no such ambition.
The events were geared toward getting lots of local, rather than national coverage.

Crowds were modest at best, with plenty of lovely backdrops, including the final one of the trip: the candidate and Mrs. Romney avoiding shouted questions while walking through the sand on the Lake Michigan beach.
Don Gonyea, NPR News, Holland, Michigan.
It's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Guy Raz.
Just outside Washington, D.C., right at the entry point of Prince George's County in Maryland, is an unassuming suburb called Capitol Heights.
And just off Central Avenue, around the corner from an industrial zone of warehouses, there's a grove of trees behind an old school bus depot.
And right there is where you'll find a priceless piece of American history.
We are in the Ridgeley Rosenwald School.
It was built in 1927.
That's Stephanie Deustch.
She's the author of our book today.
It's called ""You Need a School House: Booker T.
Washington, Julius Rosenwald, and the Building of Schools for the Segregated South."" We met her at this old, restored schoolhouse built with money from a man named Julius Rosenwald.
He was the president of Sears and Roebuck, and one of the biggest philanthropists of his day back in the early 20th century.
Rosenwald partnered with Booker T.
Washington to build thousands of schools for African-American children all across the South - like this one, Ridgeley Rosenwald, in Capitol Heights, Maryland.
Well, I guess the first and most striking thing is the windows.
These nine-over-nine paned windows were very distinctive, very typical of Rosenwald schools.
And very handy for providing light in the early years, when many of the buildings had no electricity.
This school educated hundreds of African-American children up until the time it was shut down after desegregation.
Today, it's been beautifully restored to serve as a community center and a museum.
Ninety-one-year-old Mildred Ridgeley Gray is also here this afternoon.
She remembers those early years well.
Not only did her family donate the land for the schoolhouse but she, herself, was a student at this school.
I was 6 years old.
The first day you walked in.
The first day I walked in.
Do you remember about that - anything about that first day?
My oldest sister was my teacher, and I was very - insist that I had to call her Miss Maddie.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
Miss Maddie would go on to teach two more generations of kids at the school, including Mildred's daughter Laverne.
And Mildred herself eventually became a school principal and an administrator.
Now, while Julius Rosenwald is largely forgotten today, his portrait once hung in all of the schools he helped to pay for.
And Mildred Gray says all of her classmates knew who he was.
Absolutely.
Absolutely.
They - the teachers told you, this is a man who gave money to help build this school.
That is correct.
Huh, that's interesting.
That was said in the school.
That was said in the home.
In my home, we were very much aware.
Rosenwald was one of the richest men in America.
And when he decided to start giving his money away, he gave most of it to help persecuted Jewish communities in Europe.
But Stephanie Deutsch says a race riot in his hometown of Springfield, Illinois, in 1908 made Rosenwald think twice about the treatment of African-Americans in his own country.
Booker T.
Washington's autobiography.
I mean, I just graduated from high school a year, two years ago.
The Washington Passport Agency is working from six in the morning to eleven at night.
Downstairs is where they accept applications in person, but only for people traveling within the next three days.
Upstairs is where the real work is done.
The walls are lined with boxes, stacked four or five feet high, filled with applications.
The boxes are labeled expedited or routine and color-coded to let the passport agency personnel know which to tackle first.
In one small room, printers cranked out more than 15,000 passports a week.
The State Department wouldn't allow any interviews in the passport agency though employees seemed eager to show that they're working hard.
Outside, the people lining up wondered just what's going on inside those offices.
Many complained about the bureaucratic nightmare they face getting passports for themselves or for their children.
My name is Christopher Lee and this is Jocelyn Lee.
And we live on Andrews Air Force Base, and we sent our passport application in on March 16th.
We followed all the rules.
We did everything the way they wanted us to and wound up spending countless hours on line.
Ms.

MONICA GURTS(ph) (Passport Applicant): I feel bad for the folks in the offices because these folks, are, you know, overworked and getting the, you know, brunt end of the deal because you've got irritated folks walking in.

That was Monica Gurts who had rare kind words of support for the passport agency employees and the State Department workers who gave up their regular jobs to stand out here and help people through the process.
Some say Department employees joke about the pull they feel between going to Baghdad or the passport agencies.

The Consular Affairs Department seems to be trying to sweeten the deal providing travel expenses and a per diem for those who take up temporary assignments in the understaffed passport agencies from New Hampshire to Hawaii.
Michele Kelemen, NPR News, Washington.
A Russian cargo plane took off from Germany this morning with a very unusual load - almost 600 pounds of highly enriched uranium.
This was the biggest shipment ever in a joint U.S.-Russian program.
The idea is to keep nuclear material off the black market and out of the hands of terrorists.
NPR's Emily Harris watched the operation in Dresden.

First, 10 police cars drove out of the Rosendorf Research Center when the convoy taking the uranium to the airport started to move at 2:41 a.m., then out came a large truck followed by 16 more police vehicles plus an emergency medical team.
The uranium in the truck is called fresh fuel, because it's not been used to produce power.
Despite the intense security, fresh fuel is not dangerous by itself says Udo Hevic(ph), the head of the company closing down the Rosendorf Research reactor.
